Lighter weight and less room to affect barrel harmonics over the various piston options. Yes you can make piston setups at such perfect tolerances they can compete but it's expensive and slower. Perfect for mass produced rifle caliber DMRs like AR10s. Not bad for common infantry guns either.

Carbon and lead doesn't just disappear, it just ends up somewhere else.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56079075
They are definitely useful when you expect to be shot at by small arms.
First of all, every trained shooter will aim to hit your torso, just because it increases hit probability.
Second, a hit in the thoracic cavity will most likely kill you. Maybe not instantly, but odds are you will die.

So why are most people skipping sideplates? Likely because the added protection does not justify the added weight and especially the restriction in your movement. Also, they not properly cover the thoracic cavity.

If you are expecting to get shot at by IDF, you will likely want to get a flak vest.

It was used in combat in a shitty position with barely trained Volkssturm boys and did well according to the report of a British major.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Previous >>55996404
Dawn of Black Friday deals edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>56067996
Constitution IS a Royal Navy tier name- the US mostly stuck with RN customs back then, and it's good. The rest mostly suck. I'm fine with picking one category of ships to name after states, too. Most states have cool names, and there's only 50 of them, so they're usually reserved for some of the most powerful capital ships. USS Alabama, USS Nevada, etc. sound good to me. New Hampshire can suck a dick, though.

Let's just cut down to it. The problem is naming ships after people, cities, and battles. Most cities do not sound cool, and who gives a fuck about just one city, anyway. Plus, there's too many. Likewise, people's names are rarely good for ships. There are some exceptions, but not many. Really, even if you're naming it after a badass, it still feels weird and patronizing. Nevermind the fact that the US frequently names ships after civilian senators, civil rights activists, and shitty presidents. The latter is the most obnoxious to me. Now, it's okay to name some ships after battles, but that really comes down to what the battle was killed. Tarawa isn't the worst name ever, but it doesn't sound good either. Plus, you're still naming your ship after foreign land, even if you meant to refer to the battle.

Also, stop naming ships ''America''. That's fucking silly.

Of course, there are exceptions to everything. Ticonderoga, Bunker Hill, Nimitz, Spruance, Topeka, etc. sound good to me.

I still can't believe we have a ship called The Sullivans. THE Sullivans. USS The Sullivans. What a dumb fucking name. Just call it Sullivan, or Sullivans.

>>56049611
From a military standpoint, not really.
From a law enforcement standpoint, if you really stretch the meaning of "supersoldier," kinda.
Consider what Knights and modern SWAT teams have in common: a much greater amount of gear than what would be economic to equip an actual army with, deployment requirements that are kind of randomly dispersed in a way that makes mobilization of signifigant amounts of manpower not really viable, and frequent political situations that makes losing manpower undesirable.
Knights kinda suck from a cost/utility perspective in war, especially once you start moving to the Modern era where you get stuff like crossbows that can reliably penetrate even Plate at close distances, let alone guns, but they are very good at dispensing the kings justice since they're consistantly "on call" in a way that normal armies can't be as much.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>56049611
It really depends on what kind of supersoldier you're making here. The definition is so broad and there are so many examples proposed in fiction that fill so many different types of niches for so many specific, in-universe purposes, it's hard to give a definitive answer. As others in this thread have said, the main issue is the value of a supersoldier's training, equipment and augmentation comparable to the advantage they bring to the battlefiel. By and large, the better option for most modern militaries would be to just stick with outfitting normal, regular footsoliders with standard equipment and faster, cheaper training. That's not to say the role would never be implemented, there are specialist roles in military and paramilitary organisation that are time-intensive and cost a lot of money in training for the sake of outfitting a person to fulfil a particular strategic niche; it's literal what special forces are. Consider this along with the fact that most supersoldiers you see in media are written to fill that exact role as special force operators working alongside standard military operatives (Spartans and UNSC Marines, Astartes and Imperial Guard, etc.) then it's not hard to imagine a potential future where such combatants exist. It's merely a matter of what kind of appearance and role they'd take, and whether or not something else in our world emerges that changes the way warfare is waged that makes the idea of soldiers to begin with obsolete.
